appDisplayName: WSJT-X: Digital Modes for Weak Signal Communications in Amateur Radio
description:
Weak signal ham radio communication

WSJT-X is a computer program designed to facilitate basic amateur radio communication using very weak signals. The first four letters in the program name stand for “Weak Signal communication by K1JT,” while the suffix “-X” indicates that WSJT-X started as an extended branch of an earlier program, WSJT, first released in 2001. WSJT-X implements communication protocols or "modes" called FST4, FST4W, FT4, FT8, JT4, JT9, JT65, Q65, MSK144, and WSPR, as well as one called Echo for detecting and measuring your own radio signals reflected from the Moon.  These modes were designed for making reliable, confirmed QSOs under extreme weak-signal conditions.
WSJT-X 2.7.0 is a General Availability (GA) release, the first since
version 2.6.1. Major enhancements include a new companion program
QMAP, new Special Operating Activities "Q65 Pileup" and "SuperFox", a
new "Message System" feature, an option to update Hamlib at the click
of a button, and various other improvements.

- QMAP is of particular interest to those engaged in Earth-Moon-Earth
  (EME) communication. It provides single-polarization receive-only
  capabilities for any one of the 60-second submodes of Q65 and the
  associated 30-second submode with the same tone spacing. It lets
  you monitor all corresponding traffic in a 90 kHz sub-band while
  conducting EME QSOs in the usual way with WSJT-X.

- Q65 Pileup mode helps DX operators using Q65 in circumstances with
  many simultaneous callers and very weak signals, such as those
  experienced by 6-meter EME DXpeditions.

- SuperFox mode behaves operationally like the old-style Fox and Hounds
  mode but uses a new constant envelope waveform for Fox’s transmissions.
  Messages can be transmitted simultaneously to as many as 9 Hounds with
  no signal-strength penalty, resulting in a system gain of about +10 dB
  compared to the older Fox-and-Hound operation using 5 slots.

- The new Message System allows structured plain text messages to be
  sent to your QSO partner to request QSY to another band or mode, or
  to send any one of a number of canned messages. This feature can be
  especially useful during contests.

- A button labeled "Update Hamlib" lets you download and install the
  latest version of the rig-control features in Hamlib.

- The cty.dat file can now be updated by clicking a single button.

Numerous other enhancements and bug fixes make operation smoother and
more intuitive. Features for main-window switching between modes have
been enhanced so that submode and status of the Sh and Fast checkboxes
are saved and restored by mode. Note that the "Update Hamlib" feature
is currently available only in Windows.
